questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency, 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have:

choices.text: High plasma phosphate, High Ca2+ levels and tetanus.
Low plasma Ca2+ level, tetany, and Trousseau sign.
Low plasma phosphate and high Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.
Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.solution:
Parathyroid hormone deficiency leads to low Ca+2 level, tetany and Trousseau sign.

(Please differentiate with tetanus which is caused by infection with the bacteria Clostridium tetani)

Actions of PTH include

  • PTH stimulates bone resorption, causing the release of calcium into the extracel­lular fluid;
  • PTH increases reabsorption of calcium and decreases phosphate reabsorption by the renal tubules, leading to reduced excretion of calcium and increased excretion of phosphate; and
  • PTH is necessary for the conversion of 25­-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25­ dihydroxycholecalciferol, which, in turn, increases calcium absorption by the intestines. 

So, a deficiency of PTH would lead to low Ca+2 levels and high Phosphate levels. 

Symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia - mild circumoral or digital numbness and paresthesia, carpopedal spasm, or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias. Chvostek and Trousseaus sign may be elicited. ECG changes may show QT prolongation or QRS changes.

The signs of tetany in humans include Chvostek sign, a quick contraction of the ipsilateral facial muscles elicited by tapping over the facial nerve at the angle of the jaw, and Trousseau sign, a spasm of the muscles of the upper extremity that causes flexion of the wrist and thumb.

Management - Acute symptomatic hypocalcemia is an emergency and must be treated with IV and oral calcium and vitamin D replacement. 10 ml IV calcium gluconate 10% is given slowly. Supplemental Magnesium may also be required due to the synergestic actions of calcium and magnesium. 

A hand being held similarly to Trousseau's sign (below).

Related Pearl: Summary of hormones that regulate Ca2+ levels

questions.text: The COPRA was instated in India, in 1986. This legislation is related to ______
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights.

  • It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are
    • Right to safety
    • Right to be informed
    • Right to be heard
    • Right to choose
    • Right to seek redressal
    • Right to consumer education

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy child is brought to the clinic with the findings below. He was born at 38-weeks gestation to a mother with HIV. Which other condition can you expect the patient to develop in the clinical stage that the patient is currently in?
questions.solution:
This child with Kaposi's sarcoma (image below) and oesophageal candidiasis (image above) has HIV Stage IV according to the WHO staging of HIV/AIDS in children with confirmed HIV infection. The other feature seen in this stage is CMV retinitis.

Other Options:

Persistent parotid enlargement (Option A) is seen in Stage 2

Herpes zoster (Option B) is seen in Stage 2

Extensive molluscum contagiosum (Option D) is seen in Stage 2

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema
  • Herpes zoster
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Stage 3

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis
  • Lymph node TB
  • Pulmonary TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Stage 4

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)
  • Chronic Herpes Simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi Sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, unexplained weight loss, visual blurring, genital thrush, and lethargy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is hyperglycemia.

The symptoms of hyperglycemia include:

  • Polyuria
  • Polydipsia
  • Weight loss
  • Fatigue
  • Blurry vision
  • Frequent superficial infections (vaginitis, fungal skin infections)
  • Slow healing of skin lesions after minor trauma.

Note: The metabolic derangements occurring in these patients are due to osmotic diuresis and a catabolic state caused by urinary loss of glucose and increased muscle breakdown. Blurred vision results from changes in the water content of the lens.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of tracheo-esophageal fistula?
questions.solution:
The type C Tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF), is the most common type.

TEF is an abnormal communication between Esophagus and Trachea.

Type C is most common - it has proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF (the proximal blind pouch ends at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF)

Types and frequency of TEF (Gross classification)

  • Type A  (~7%): Pure esophageal atresia. A long gap between the two esophageal blind pouches. No fistula.
  • Type B (2-3%): The upper esophageal pouch abnormally connects to the trachea (proximal TEF). The lower esophageal pouch ends blindly.
  • Type C (~86%): The lower esophageal pouch abnormally connects to the trachea (distal TEF). The upper esophageal pouch ends blindly.
  • Type D (<1%): Both the upper and lower esophageal pouch have an abnormal connection with the trachea (both proximal and distal TEF), in two separate locations.
  • Type E (4%):  No esophageal atresia. Abnormal connection between the esophagus and the trachea present (H-type TEF). 
  • Type F (<1%): Congenital esophageal stenosis. No fistula. 

TEF is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: Amsel’s criteria for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis include all except _______
questions.solution:
Abundant polymorphs is not included in Amsel’s criteria.

Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odour on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

At least three of the four criteria should be present to confirm the diagnosis.

Bacterial vaginosis, in which Gardnerella vaginalis is the main causative agent, presents with a vaginal discharge without pruritis. Discharge is homogenous, creamy/greyish white, with fishy odor, and adherent to the vaginal wall

On microscopy, there is no abundance of polymorphs in a case of bacterial vaginosis as it is just an alteration of flora and not an inflammation.

  • The diagnosis is based on wet smear and culture.
  • The smear reveals clean background with few inflammatory cells and other organ­isms, but scanty lactobacilli. Many epithelial cells present a granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, the so-called clue cells. Gram stain is 90% sensitive.

Metronidazole, an antibiotic with activity against anaerobes but poor activity against lactobacilli, is the drug of choice for the treatment of BV. A dose of 500 mg administered orally twice a day for 7 days should be used or the same can be given as gel, if available.

 

 

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginalis

Candida albicans
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomas vaginalis-parasitic infection Fungal infection
Etiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual trans-mission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odor, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test Whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is seen in cubitus valgus. 

Cubitus valgus deformity can occur as a complication of fracture of lateral condyle of the humerus.

Fracture of lateral condyle of humerus occurs when the patient falls on the hand with the elbow extended and forced into varus (forearm pushed medially with respect to elbow). A large fragment of bone including the lateral condyle breaks off and is pulled away by the attached wrist extensors. The normal 3-point bony relationship at the elbow is lost. 

It is a Salter-Harris type IV injury. As it is an intra-articular fracture, it is surgically managed by open reduction and internal fixation. 

Common complications include stiffness of elbow, nonunion and cubitus valgus deformity. This deformity can lead to chronic injury to the ulnar nerve (tardy ulnar palsy). Friction neuritis of the ulnar nerve occurs as it moves over the medial epicondyle in cubitus valgus leading to late ulnar nerve palsy.

questions.text: The most common cutaneous manifestation in systemic lupus erythematosus is ________
questions.solution:
The most common cutaneous manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus is photosensitivity.

In decreasing order, the cutaneous manifestations in SLE are:

  • Photosensitivity (63%)
  • Raynaud's Phenomenon (60%)
  • Malar Rash (51%)
  • Chronic Urticaria >36 hrs (44%)
  • Non-scarring Alopecia (40%)
  • Mouth Ulceration (31%)

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Antibody Clinical utility
Antinuclear antibodies Best screening test 
Anti-Sm Most specific for SLE
Anti-dsDNA

High titers correlate with disease severity

Increases the risk of nephritis
Anti-Ro(SS-A)

Predisposes to subacute cutaneous lupus, neonatal lupus with congenital heart blocks.

Decreases the risk of nephritis
Anti-La(SS-B) Decreases the risk of nephritis
Antineuronal  Associated with CNS lupus
Antiribosomal P Associated with psychosis or depression in CNS lupus
Anti-RNP High titers are diagnostic of mixed connective tissue disease
Antihistone Associated with drug-induced lupus

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for pre eclampsia is:
questions.solution:
Continuous epidural anesthesia is the first choice for most patients with preeclampsia during labor, vaginal delivery, and cesarean section.

Pre-eclampsia patients have a risk of severe airway edema, which makes intubation difficult. Thus continuous epidural anesthesia is advantageous as it avoids the need for intubation. Besides, continuous epidural anesthesia can improve uteroplacental perfusion and also decrease catecholamine secretion.

But one major prerequisite for regional anesthesia in preeclamptic patients is normal platelet count and normal coagulation. Coagulopathy is a contraindication for regional anesthesia.Minimal platelet count for regional anesthesia is 100,000/μL, but some cases can be taken up with a platelet count as low as 70,000/μL.

General anesthesia is indicated in patients with coagulopathy and in severe pre-eclampsia with complications. Spinal anesthesia can be given in mild pre-eclampsia but hypotension associated with spinal anesthesia limits its use in moderate to severe pre-eclampsia.

questions.text: The characteristic features of Tourette's disorder include all of the following except ______.

choices.text: Persistence of tics  for at least 6 months
No tic-free period of more than three consecutive months in 1 year.
Presence of at least one vocal tic

questions.solution:
Tourette's syndrome is diagnosed when there is a persistence of tics for at least 1 year.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to vocal tics that can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting, barking noises, or shouted words, which may be obscenities.

Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD).

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

  • Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at some time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.
  • The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.
  • Onset is before age of 18 years.
  • The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis).
Management:

Behavioural interventions are the first line of treatment. Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases. Tics require treatment when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. 

In mild cases, where academic performance or social life is not affected, the first line of management is to provide psychoeducation, followed by a wait-and-watch strategy.

For severe cases:

  • Behavioural interventions:
    • Habit reversal
    • Exposure and response prevention
  • Pharmacological treatment:
    • Antipsychotics like risperidone
    • Noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine
    • Alternative treatments such as tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol

questions.text: Axillary artery is divided into 3 parts by:
questions.solution:
The axillary artery is divided into 3 parts by the pectoralis minor muscle.

The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery. It extends from the outer border of 1st rib to the lower border of Teres Major.

Pectoralis Minor divides the artery into 3 parts (proximal to, posterior to and lateral to the muscle).

  Relation to Pectoralis minor Branches
1st part Lies proximally Superior thoracic artery
2nd part Lies posteriorly Thoracoacromial trunk
3rd part Lies laterally

Subscapular artery

Anterior circumflex humeral artery

Posterior circumflex humeral artery

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
Liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most of gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis:

  • Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors.
  • Gluconeogenesis occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney.
  • Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.
  • Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted to back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle.
  • Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as Cahill cycle.
  • Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

questions.text: A 25-year old man presents with chronic anemia and gall stones. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. His peripheral blood smear showed spherocytes as given in the image. What is the mode of the inheritance of the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The above image showing spherocytes in the peripheral blood smear and, along with the history, strongly suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis. Inheritance of hereditary spherocytosis is mainly autosomal dominant.

It is a structural RBC disorder making the RBCs more spheroid, less deformable, and more vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. This decreases the lifespan of RBCs.

questions.text: Latanoprost used topically in glaucoma primarily acts by ______.
questions.solution:
Prostaglandin analogues act by increasing uveoscleral outflow. 

Examples: Latanoprost, bimatoprost, travoprost. 

Among these, bimatoprost also increases the trabecular outflow.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: The characteristic appearance of oesophagus on barium swallow, as shown in the image below,  is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The corkscrew appearance of the esophagus is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

  • Diffuse/distal esophageal spasm (DES) is a motility disorder of the esophagus.
  • On barium swallow, DES may appear as a corkscrew or rosary bead esophagus, but this is uncommon.
  • Manometry is the gold-standard diagnostic test.

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterised by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing.

In achalasia single contrast esophagogram shows, dilatation of the esophagus with a bird beak deformity near the gastroesophageal junction.

In esophageal carcinoma barium study will show irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins.

Double-contrast esophagram shows a large, flat ulceration (arrow) in the distal esophagus in a patient with CMV esophagitis.
